importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating recent developments in China's export controls on rare-earth metals.
The effective date of the new export restrictions on rare-earth metals and related technological equipment, marking when the controls will officially apply.
The anticipated date of the Trump-Xi meeting during the APEC summit in South Korea, which is a key diplomatic event where China's new controls serve as strategic leverage.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period between the announcement of new export controls and their effective date, during which foreign companies must apply for licenses, and negotiations between the US and China are underway.

keyTakeAways: China has significantly tightened export controls on rare-earth metals, including five new additions (holmium, erbium, thulium, europium, ytterbium) and expanding restrictions to 12 out of 17 rare-earth elements.
The restrictions include export controls on specialized technological equipment used to refine rare-earth metals, effective from December 1, 2025.
Foreign companies must obtain special approvals from Beijing and explain the intended use of products containing rare-earth metals, especially those with at least 0.1% heavy rare-earth content.
China justified the controls under national security grounds, citing dual-use applications and evidence of sensitive transfers to military or hostile actors.
Rare-earth metals are essential for critical technologies including electric vehicles, lithium-ion batteries, AI semiconductors, and defence systems like F-35 jets and missiles.
The US is the largest importer of Chinese rare-earth products, sourcing 70% of its rare-earth compounds from China between 2020 and 2023, making it highly vulnerable to supply disruptions.
China’s actions are interpreted as a strategic signal ahead of the Trump-Xi meeting at the APEC summit, aiming to strengthen its negotiating leverage in ongoing trade talks.

The move reflects China’s dominant role in global rare-earth supply—producing at least 60% and processing 90% of the world’s supply—allowing it to exert significant influence over global supply chains.
Experts note that while China may face economic costs due to supply chain interdependence, the move signals its intent to weaponize its supply chain position.
Certain exports for emergency medical needs, public health emergencies, or disaster relief remain exempt from the restrictions.

namedEntities.name: China
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country that has implemented new export controls on rare-earth metals and related technologies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China is the world’s largest producer and processor of rare-earth metals and has used this position as a strategic tool in international trade negotiations.

namedEntities.name: United States
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country that is heavily dependent on Chinese rare-earth imports and is directly affected by China’s new export controls.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The US is the largest importer of Chinese rare-earth metals and products, making it particularly vulnerable to supply disruptions and strategic pressure from China.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The former U.S. President, expected to meet with Xi Jinping during the APEC summit.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump is a key diplomatic figure whose upcoming meeting with China’s leader marks a strategic moment where China’s export controls are used to strengthen its negotiating position.

namedEntities.name: Xi Jinping
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Chinese leader, counterpart to Donald Trump in upcoming diplomatic talks.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: As China’s political leader, Xi Jinping represents the decision-making authority behind the export controls, signaling China’s strategic intent in bilateral trade negotiations.

namedEntities.name: APEC (Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A regional economic forum where U.S. President Trump is expected to visit South Korea to meet with Chinese officials.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The APEC summit serves as the diplomatic setting for the Trump-Xi meeting, making the timing of China’s export controls a calculated pre-meeting signal.

namedEntities.name: South Korea
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country where the APEC summit is being hosted.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The location of the APEC summit provides the context for the timing of China’s new export controls, which are strategically positioned before the high-level meeting.

namedEntities.name: Rare-earth metals
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A group of 17 metallic elements, including the lanthanides and scandium and yttrium.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: These metals are essential for modern technology and defence systems, making them a critical lever in global trade and geopolitical strategy.

namedEntities.name: Holmium, Erbium, Thulium, Europium, Ytterbium
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Five specific rare-earth metals added to China’s export control list in 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Their inclusion expands China’s control over a broader range of high-value, technologically critical rare-earth elements.

namedEntities.name: Samarium, Gadolinium, Terbium, Dysprosium, Lutetium, Scandium, Yttrium
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Seven rare-earth metals previously restricted by China in April 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: These elements were already under export control, and their continued restriction shows a cumulative tightening of China’s regulatory stance.

namedEntities.name: Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An American think tank that has analyzed the strategic importance of rare-earth metals.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: CSIS provided expert analysis on how rare-earth metals are used in defence systems and how China’s controls affect US industrial security.

namedEntities.name: Gracelin Baskaran
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Director of the CSIS Critical Minerals Security Program.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She provided expert commentary on how China’s restrictions deepen US technological vulnerabilities and weaken its defence capabilities.

namedEntities.name: Kristin Vekasi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Mansfield chair of Japan and Indo-Pacific Affairs at the University of Montana.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She interpreted China’s actions as a strategic signalling move ahead of the Trump-Xi meeting, emphasizing the role of supply chain leverage.

namedEntities.name: F-35 fighter jets
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major U.S. defence system that uses rare-earth metals.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: These jets are a key example of how rare-earth metals are integral to modern defence technology, making them a target of China’s export controls.

namedEntities.name: Virginia and Columbia-class submarines
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. naval vessels that rely on rare-earth elements.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: These advanced submarines depend on rare-earth materials, highlighting the strategic impact of China's controls on U.S. naval power.

namedEntities.name: Tomahawk missiles, Predator UAVs, Joint Direct Attack Munition (JDAM)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. military systems that use rare-earth components.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: These systems illustrate the breadth of military applications, making China’s controls a significant threat to U.S. defence capabilities.

namedEntities.name: Artificial Intelligence (AI) technology
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A domain where rare-earth metals are used in semiconductor production.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The use of rare-earth metals in AI semiconductors shows their role in high-tech innovation and national competitiveness.

namedEntities.name: U.S. Geological Survey
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S. government agency that reported on China’s share of rare-earth exports.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Its data confirms U.S. dependence on Chinese rare-earth imports, reinforcing the vulnerability of American supply chains.

namedEntities.name: Observatory of Economic Complexity (OEC)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An organization that tracks global trade flows.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It provided data on U.S. imports of Chinese rare-earth products, showing the scale of dependency.

summaryOfNewsArticle: China has announced new and expanded export controls on 12 of the 17 rare-earth metals, including five new additions (holmium, erbium, thulium, europium, ytterbium), effective from December 1, 2025. The restrictions apply to both rare-earth metals and specialized refining equipment, requiring foreign companies to obtain special approvals and disclose intended uses. China cites national security and dual-use risks—particularly sensitive transfers to military actors—as justification. The move comes just weeks before a high-stakes diplomatic meeting between U.S. President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping at the APEC summit in South Korea, suggesting it is a strategic signaling effort to strengthen China’s negotiating leverage. The United States, which imports 70% of its rare-earth compounds from China, faces significant disruptions in defence and civilian technologies such as electric vehicles, AI systems, and medical devices. Analysts from CSIS and the University of Montana interpret this as a calculated move to exploit China’s dominant position in the rare-earth supply chain, potentially widening the technological and industrial gap between the two powers. Exports for emergency medical and disaster relief remain exempt.
title: China tightens export controls on rare-earth metals: Why this matters
